instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

threads.title: iMac 820-3126 Half Fan Spin
threads.message:
Hello

This iMac is with white screen of death and I just bought a K2100 to solve this issue

However when dissambly I break 1 cap (C3634) and had to put back R3604. 

Not sure if I damage anyother thing. However I did a GOOD visual inspection and didn't find anything

Now it only has 1 LED light on the motherboard and half fan spin
Any idea where to look for the problem.

Can I use my lab PSU to inject voltage on the main rail? 12V?

threads.title: iMac 820-3126 Half Fan Spin
threads.message:
C3634 isn't critical, can be left out.
Check diode mode between its pads.

threads.title: iMac 820-3126 Half Fan Spin
threads.message:
DIODE between C3634 pads

black probe on PIN 2 GND
red probe PIN 1 PP3V3_S3

= 0.568v

threads.title: iMac 820-3126 Half Fan Spin
threads.message:
For repair purpose, you can use 12 lab PSU.
Removing CMOS battery will force board turn on when power is applied.

Just in case, check if starts in SMC bypass mode.

REMOVED THE CMOS = WHICH I UNDERSTAND = AUTO TURN ON

If so please confirm wich is the right pad/component to touch with the tweezer?

threads.title: iMac 820-3126 Half Fan Spin
threads.message:

As you get S3 voltages, board started power on sequence.
Don't need to trigger SMC_ONOFF_L; S5010 pads can be used, if really need that.

Do you get 12V_S0?

threads.title: iMac 820-3126 Half Fan Spin
threads.message:
Mmmmh, this old machine has 12V_S0 FET placed into its PSU.
Injecting 12V from lab PSU directly doesn't help.
You can try to run a wire between 12V_G3H and 12V_S0, for this purpose.
Be sure first no short there.

I recommend to use original known good PSU.

threads.title: iMac 820-3126 Half Fan Spin
threads.message: Is there a test to check if original PSU is good? It came working normally. The problem was white screen of death VGA problem.

threads.title: iMac 820-3126 Half Fan Spin
threads.message:
Be aware, working with high voltage device is dangerous!!!

According with schematic, iMac PSU can be tested forcing PS_ON signal; it should bring on 12V_S0 output.

threads.title: iMac 820-3126 Half Fan Spin
threads.message:
I don't recommend to work with PSU alone.
If PSU is connected to MLB, trigger SMC_ONOFF_L; PS_ON should change its status.

threads.title: iMac 820-3126 Half Fan Spin
threads.message:
SMC_ONOFF_L must be triggered for short time only, like pressing power button.
PS_ON should go low at same time.

When 12V_S0 tries to appear, check for pulse at big coils and ALL_SYS_PWRGD.
Be sure no short on any coil...

threads.title: iMac 820-3126 Half Fan Spin
threads.message:
Yes when I trigger SMC_ONOFF_L I use a tweezer on both sides of the cap I mentioned above. Is it the correct way? If not please detail how to do it properly.

PS_ON =  3.96 for some seconds and then goes to 0 and then back to 3.96
ALL_SYS_PWRGD = 0.030v and then goes to 0V and then tries to go back
12V_S0 =   Its around 0.500V and then it tries to go up sometimes it shows 8V / 9V and then back to 0.500v in loop.

L7100
PIN 1 =  Same behavior as 12V_S0
PIN 2 = Same behavior as 12V_S0

threads.title: iMac 820-3126 Half Fan Spin
threads.message:
In my opinion, is more convenient to solder a wire on corresponding pad os S5010 and touch any metal placa to simulate power button.
This way also helps you to test starting in SMC bypass mode.

I didn't see any mention about output voltages from pages 68, 69 & 71.

Trigger SMC_ONOFF_L more times; helps to catch higher pulses...

threads.title: iMac 820-3126 Half Fan Spin
threads.message:
You can't test the board without 12V_S0.
You can try to make a bypass from 12V_S5 to 12V_S0.
This may not work, if PCH timing is not respected, for power on sequence.

Use a spare iMac PSU, to work on the desk.
You don't need to connect internal LCD, nor speakers.

threads.title: iMac 820-3126 Half Fan Spin
threads.message:
An onboard measurment for resistor can give you different reading than nominal.
That's normal, more components connected there affect onboard value.

"12V_S0_PWRCTL is not named this on the boardview file"
I'm sure you can locate one component connected to it on schematic in boardview too.
Learn how to use schematic/boardview; such reply is not acceptable for a technician!

Did you test it now with its original iMac PSU?
Remember to remove the short between 12V_G3H and 12V_S0.

threads.title: iMac 820-3126 Half Fan Spin
threads.message:
The problem with lab PSU is that PCH timings are not respected; 12V_S0 being present even in S5 state.
If you can confirm that a good working board boots in this way, then is safe to continue the repair process with lab PSU.
Until then, is better to remove original PSU and use it with the board on the desk.

Mentioned pages contain lot of secondary voltages.
You must be sure first there is no short; on any output rail.
Then check for voltage pulse.
Some of these secondary voltages have a power good signal, which is needed to get correct ALL_SYS_PWRGD.
For example, on page 68, 1V05_S0 is what you need to check (L7420).
On page 69 should check (pulse) voltage for D and S of Q7500.
You forget to check L7850 on page 71.

"Yes I tried SMC bypass and its same behavior I already told you"
Did you try it after changing R7082?

Check for pulse at pin 8 & 11 of U7050; also at L7201.

threads.title: iMac 820-3126 Half Fan Spin
threads.message:
"PM_SLP_S3_L = 3.30V"
Then you MUST get 12V_S0 too.
Check pins 11, 12, 13 & 14 of U6900.

threads.title: iMac 820-3126 Half Fan Spin
threads.message:
So PM_EN_P12V_S0_FET is present.
Check if PS_ON stays low at same time.
12V_S0 FET is inside PSU.
If no short, or low resistance to ground, 12V_S0 MUST come on.
If not, try another PSU...

threads.title: iMac 820-3126 Half Fan Spin
threads.message:
If you have the boards on hand, check for similar MOSFET; same package style and size.
Then compare between schematics; must have the same pins configuration.
Google also helps you to find nominal voltage/current, for better comparison.

threads.title: iMac 820-3126 Half Fan Spin
threads.message:
You've said to have scrap boards to get an equivalent.
Learn how to compare and interchange components, when is possible.

Check diode mode to ground on the mentioned connectors (especially power lines).
Do this w/ and w/o HDD/ODD connected.
Then compare the values; shouldn't get any short, or very low values.
Be sure to insert the cables correctly.

threads.title: iMac 820-3126 Half Fan Spin
threads.message:
With HDD POWER (J4511) connected to the board
ODD NOT connected as requested

LED 1 = Stable Working
LED 2 = Bling as soon as the power cable is connected and then turn off totally
LED 3 = OFF
LED 4 = OFF

PP12V_S5 = 11.98
PP12V_S0 = tries to go to 11.98 and then it drops to 1V ... 0.300 ... 0.100 and its in LOOP
PP3V42 = 
PP5V_S5 = 4.96 
PP3V3_S5 = 3.30
PP5V_S0 = 0V but looks like it tries to go up, but it doesnt show 5V at any moment
PP3V3_S3 = 0v but it tris to go up and shows 3.30 for a second also in a LOOP
PP5V_S3 = Tries to go up but doesnt show any number at the multimeter

threads.title: iMac 820-3126 Half Fan Spin
threads.message:

Also remove HDD from the end cable; keep the cable connected to J4521.

Do you have any SSD connected to J4530/31?

I never faced such issue, just try to help you.
You've already did a mistake connecting ODD in reverse way.
That could cause weird damage on the board.
Call a magician, if you feel better.

threads.title: iMac 820-3126 Half Fan Spin

Then (you should imagine somehow), connect 5V_S0_SATA and GND to SSD using a pair of wires.

We have many posts here, not easy to remember all of them.
Not sure if you disconnect L4511, for test.

threads.title: iMac 820-3126 Half Fan Spin
threads.message:
To SDD NO; you can use a SATA power cable from a desktop PC.
Apart of power overload, I don't see anything elese common between thunderbolt and SATA port.
Just told you how to discard anything else related with SATA; like disconnecting L4511 (did it?).

You can't discard original iMac PSU, so that is still a possible reason.
Maybe it can't support SATA, or/and thunderbolt consumption.

Still not sure about board behavior.
"I REMOVE the idea of SATA being bad since it does not have any issue with it only connected"
Do you mean board stays on (chime, USB activity) with HDD connetced now?

Connecting together 12V_S0 with 12V_G3H may not like to PCH; because of timing issues.
I think you tried this on the first posts, don't remember now.

Just try connecting 12V from lab PSU to pins 1-3 of J600 at same time; set amp limit to max.
Disconnect any cable from iMac PSU and MLB first.
